title: Notes on Tanu Malakul Na Ayudhaya
body:
### Celebrating the work of 1938 Bangkok born artist Tanu Malakul Na Ayudhaya, a fifth generation artist of the Malakul family, whose artistic heritage dates back to the reign of King Rama II. Tanu Malakul, a former professor of art at the Bangkok Academy of Arts, offers a colorful feast and inspiring graphic style for the eye on NFTs.

![Tanu Malakul Na Ayudhaya by Peter Nitsch.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/cYYJMj_be47aE8_KqoQfy.jpg?height=1642&width=1086&&&&&size=medium)

**Notes on Tanu Malakul Na Ayudhaya by Sidhijai Tanphiphat (1987)**

Tanu Malakulâ€™s artistic talent was recognized by the late Prof. Silpa Bhirasri (C. Filoci), an Italian who took up Thai citizenship and is largely regarded as the father of the Western arts movement in Thailand. Tanu Malakul was persuaded by Prof. Bhirasri to study under him at the Fine Arts University in Bangkok from 1959 to 1962.

He then furthered his studies at the Berlin Academy of Arts (S.H.F.B.K., Berlin) graduating in industrial design under the tutelage of Prof. Dr. Braun Feldweg Tanu took that opportunity to travel widely in Europe. The exposure to foreign cultures, arts and philosophy is an important step in the formative years of any budding artist as it was to Tanu Malakul.

Upon his return to Thailand in 1968, Tanu Malakul joined an industrial manufacturing conglomerate, Siam Cement Company Limited, as an industrial designer. During this period, he continued to experiment with various art styles, techniques and media and produced works which found many grateful collectors.

![Potplants in the Rain I, 2015.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/B8P4C0Td5FieH9v2hFeCI.jpg?height=914&width=1073&&&&size=medium)

His commitment to arts became total in 1972 when Tanu Malakul decided to forsake the promising corporate career and became a full time and freelance artist, a doubtful occupation at best where fame and fortune is almost unheard of in Thailand. His instincts prevailed, however. During this period of the early Seventies, Tanu Malakul was deeply concerned with the universal problems of the rapidly deteriorating environment â€“ particularly in Thailand where deforestation and the destruction of watersheds and ecological balance was starkly apparent. His work mostly in oil, expressed in abstract hard edged graphic style, inter-mixed with surreal scenes sought to dramatize the need for environmental conservation and for a more rational balance between technological and economic quests.

As a painter who has seriously experimented with surrealism and impressionism of the western contemporary styles, the traditional Thai mural painting technique became increasingly fascinating to Tanu Malakul as a means for conveying and expressing more complex concepts and themes.

![Concrete Incarnation, 1972.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/pzGGE-KNSGhbaquzQaStK.jpg?height=1115&width=1100&&&&size=medium)

Thai mural paintings executed on the interior walls of Thai Buddhist temples are mainly used to explain the teachings of the Lord Buddha to the illiterate laymen and also to illustrate important events of the Buddhist religion. Thai mural painting techniques do not adhere to the principles of perspectives and vanishing points.

Scenes often appear at equidistance to the observer ingeniously separated by trees or rocks which allow the various scenes to blend in. As such, a painting may encompass different times of the day â€“ day and night â€“ one subject may appear in different scenes of the same painting as the story unfolds, and more importantly, and object, such as a building may be portrayed as seen from 3 different directions, which is what cubism is to the western art. Such imaginative application of abstraction renders the traditional Thai mural painting techniques a powerful tool with which an artist can portray complicated stories, themes or to express complex concepts. This is what has attracted Tanu Malakul to study and apply Thai mural painting techniques to the bulk of his works.

![Once Upon a Time, 1985.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/vRWQqBWMnAIrLZMIFTATz.jpg?height=1568&width=1200&&&&size=medium)

From the mid-Nineteen Seventies onward, Tanu Malakul totally immersed himself in experimenting with traditional Thai mural painting techniques. Mostly working in acrylic on canvas. Early works ranged from his own interpretation and portrayal of classic Buddhist events such as when the Prince Siddharta recognized the futility of worldly sufferings to search for eternal peace and to eventually find enlightenment, including everyday life scenes of the early Bangkok period and other such down to earth subjects. This became an extremely prolific period although Thai paintings by nature required painstaking attention to detail to all parts of the paintings ranging from such operations as application of gold leaves and clearly outlining every object in the painting.

Inquisitive by nature, Tanu Malakul continues to study ideas, philosophies, theories and new scientific discoveries of subjects ranging from Buddhist scriptures (Tripitaka) to the theories and discoveries of modern quantum physics, cosmology and many other challenging topics.

![The Great Existance, 1982.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/mYKGzWiCeIRDjIlyalyTX.jpg?height=1457&width=1100&&&size=medium)

Tanu Malakul has developed an intriguing view that the teachings of the Lord Buddha have understood many of the natural phenomena that modern science has recently begun to explain.

For eight long years, Tanu Malakul has been conceptualizing in his mind a painting in which the relationship between the minutest elements such as a drop of water to the infinite universe and to show that such metamorphoses are consistent with the Buddhist view of the same. What were mere sketches made in the early Seventies which he was unable to develop further with Western or contemporary painting techniques suddenly became plausible in 1982 when Tanu Malakulâ€™s mastery of the incredible techniques of Thai mural painting was near total. A series of three paintings depicting the birth, enlightenment and death of the Lord Buddha are regarded easily as his most important works.

This same series of work culminated in the very large painting â€šThe Four Noble Truths' which encompassed the total concepts and contents of the aforementioned three paintings.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/1fZ5OnvMix-SrGUFH7pEq.jpg?height=1101&width=1442&&&&size=medium)

Detractors of contemporary artists working in the traditional mural painting style have contended that such artists are regressing to the past and are simply copying old subject matters and techniques. While this may be true of much of such works today, but Tanu Malakul, by virtue of his thorough understanding of the techniques of Thai painting and the social context in which the techniques were developed historically, have found new applications for it in modern times that no other Thai artist has.

![Finished portrait work in Tanu Malakul's studio, 2022.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/tRBweKCvhgKeHrpYHhijN.jpg?height=900&width=1200&&size=medium)

Apart from such â€šheavy' subjects as above mentioned, Tanu Malakul has a keen sense for appreciating the utility and beauty of all kinds of objects. He has designed and executed numerous graphic silkscreen prints for hotel wall decorations as well as hand painted furnitures, screens, table lamps and such objects d'art.

![Left: Goldfish | Right: Potplants III, 2015.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/uXgUb7bgYOZawwA_N6Vm2.jpg?height=936&width=1500&&&&size=medium)

Paradoxically, Tanu Malakul is a virtual recluse regarding the publicizing of his work, be they for commercial or for public recognition purposes, and yet he is not an introverted person. Still as a full-time artist, Tanu Malakul has not held even one exhibition of his work because his work is almost always executed upon commission.

![Potplants in the Rain II, 2015.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/3RK6EGiadbmN3dMi5b3R-.jpg?height=682&width=782&&&&size=medium)

title: Applying NFTs: Insurance
body:
![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/eTUV2iycCqO3u2M4UEFr0.png?height=260&width=1378)

[Blockchain technology](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/b/blockchain.asp), and specifically [Non Fungible Tokens (â€œNFTsâ€)](https://www.investopedia.com/non-fungible-tokens-nft-5115211), are a relatively new form of technology. The initial use case of blockchain stemmed from the 2007 [Global Financial Crisis (â€œGFCâ€)](https://www.rba.gov.au/education/resources/explainers/the-global-financial-crisis.html#:\~:text=The%20global%20financial%20crisis%20(GFC,mid%202007%20and%20early%202009.) in the form of [Satoshi Nakamotoâ€™s Bitcoin whitepaper](https://nakamotoinstitute.org/bitcoin/). This subsequently went on to inspire several forks and new crypto currencies thus disrupting the traditional finance space during the 2017 [decentralised finance (â€œDefiâ€)](https://www.forbes.com/advisor/investing/cryptocurrency/defi-decentralized-finance/#:\~:text=%E2%80%9CDecentralized%20finance%20is%20an%20unbundling,the%20hands%20of%20regular%20people.%E2%80%9D) boom. Since then there have been new applications of the technology, but we are certainly early on in the road to mainstream adoption.

[Ethereum](https://ethereum.org/en/enterprise/) has smart contract functionality which is a key ingredient for the functionality of NFTs. While most of the utility is in the experimental stage, with a huge explosion in interest during 2021, it is inevitable that there will be disruption across all industries to varying degrees.

This article focuses on the use cases within the Insurance industry. First we will review the existing challenges in the industry before covering potential solutions from NFTs and blockchain technology.

## Industry Background

The insurance sector is a highly competitive, heavily regulated industry with consumer protection being a prime focus. The GFC, driven by mortgage loans and facilitated by most stakeholders in the financial system, meant legislators increased scrutiny to mitigate systemic risk and prevent future events recurring.

The impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic saw sizeable payouts for [business interruption](https://www.abi.org.uk/products-and-issues/topics-and-issues/coronavirus-hub/business-insurance/) insurance policies with astronomical liabilities being accrued as new legal precedents were set, following lengthy court cases. This caused a significant amount of stress on corporate balance sheets and large one off hits to their profit figures. According to [Mckinsey](https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/financial-services/our-insights/creating-value-finding-focus-global-insurance-report-2022), premium growth slowed (until last year) which would have exacerbated the issue and caused further adverse financial results.

![Source: Mckinsey](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/64OfK00OD0Lgnfn3mnWQQ.png?height=694&width=1636)

The industry incurs significant losses due to fraud. According to the [National Insurance Crime Bureau](https://www.nicb.org/news/news-releases/nicb-insurance-fraud-adds-billions-dollars-insurer-payouts-after-disasters#:\~:text=The%20NICB%20estimates%20disaster%20fraud,%246%20billion%20or%20about%207.5%25.), fraud adds five to 10 percent onto claims for disaster policies. The Pandemic caused a drop off in the number of frauds, predominantly due to restrictions on travel and the insurance products associated with this. While certain insurance products are more susceptible to fraud than others, it is certainly rife across the industry as a whole and expected to worsen as the cost of living rises thus increasing the statistical likelihood of consumers resorting to fraud to make ends meet. This is a large challenge in driving costs down, but the benefits can be passed onto customers in the form of reduced premiums should the costs be curtailed.

The systems used are archaic and cumbersome. According to [Capgemini](https://www.capgemini.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/Policy_Administration_Systems.pdf) â€œOver 60 percent of insurance providers find their policy administration systems out of date, expensive to run, inflexible and redundant. Market dynamics are forcing insurers to plot a course to replace these antiquated systemsâ€.

Insurers are constantly searching for ways of innovating to enhance IT infrastructure. According to the [Blackrock global insurance report](https://www.blackrock.com/institutions/en-ch/literature/whitepaper/global-insurance-report-2021.pdf), 59% of respondents (consisting of 362 senior executives across 26 markets) stated they intend to increase their technology spend on the previous year.

*In the next two years, how do you anticipate changing your spending/investment in your technology and infrastructure (compared with 2020 spend)?*

![Source: Blackrock](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/6mjBV9iybzbE-WqVCt4r6.png?height=808&width=1644)

Blockchain can boost transparency, aid better compliance with regulations, and build excellent products and markets. It can also drive a positive change in consumer behaviour to better benefit the wider society. We will now take a look at possible solutions available to some of these industry challenges.

## Industry Challenges & Blockchain / NFT Solutions

These solutions are general in nature and hence would need to be tailored to the specific type of insurance product offering, business model and size. The more complex listed insurers may require a more robust process which could take a longer lead time to implement when compared to a small insurance start-up which tends to be more agile.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/AurmCvpzmYNsnjHh9csk7.png?height=812&width=1430)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/YVBA_bb3bxp7FG6U7xPwr.png?height=1252&width=1432)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/KYIzbbU9q-l-P_vWNohTx.png?height=1388&width=1428)

## Real World Cases Studies

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/jA76iYs9U0Uqrs6mZtLSB.png?height=116&width=392)

1/ **[Nexus Mutual](https://nexusmutual.io/)** - Nexus Mutual uses the power of Ethereum so people can share risk together without the need for an insurance company. Areas the company look to cover include:

* Secure risk and potential bugs in smart contract code
* Be covered for events like DAO hacks or Parity multi-sig wallet issues
* Purchase Smart Contract Cover

While they are focusing on blockchain based cover, there are plans to expand to traditional types of insurance cover. The claim cover is put to a consensus vote as follows:

![Source: Nexus Mutual](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/bbzCYmnfC9BZPqRVU4czu.png?height=826&width=1226)

2/ Insurtech company, [Ryskex](https://ryskex.com/) helps provide insurers an easier way to assess and handle risks accurately through its blockchain-based platform.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wrw9RMuRTDitr2atMea_y.png?height=116&width=394)

According to [Ryskex](https://ryskex.com/) their platform *â€œallows a global network of leading investors to take on these hard to insure emerging and systemic risks. It also enables insureds to find the appropriate coverage using our parametric risk transfer solution and hedge their risks as securitised intangible assets, which can be traded transparently and securely using blockchain technology.â€*

This solution offers greater transparency for both insurers and insureds while keeping administration costs low.

3/ [Claimshare](https://claimshare.intellecteu.com/) - Insurers pay out duplicate claims for the same loss on countless occasions. The ClaimShare platform can detect and prevent â€œdouble-dippingâ€ across insurers without revealing any sensitive data. It is estimated that double dipping equates to $5-10 billion in fraud per year.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-IlanS4fRAOe9sxNIwYQa.png?height=140&width=372)

The platform integrates with existing insurance systems by using APIs, therefore a relatively seamless transition to using the new platform.

This diagram illustrates how the use of [Claimshare](https://claimshare.intellecteu.com/) amongst several insurers can prevent double dipping for the same claim:

![Source: Claimshare](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/RdqFSW6Jw-_TcAKBlx4va.png?height=864&width=1036)

## Risk Considerations

* While this new technology could lead to a competitive edge it will likely require a reasonable level of upfront investment so insurers would need to establish whether they would benefit from first mover advantage or if they are at a smaller scale could be better off delaying until the larger listed competitors have taken the plunge.
* Sharing the right amount of data to be transparent but not too much so that itâ€™s overwhelming. Competitive advantage may also be a consideration with regards to data being on the public blockchain.
* Education for all stakeholders involved may take time. Pitching the business proposal to investors for a budget to be approved for system implementation or providing guides for employees / policyholders on how to use the technology will consume company time and resources.
* Legal framework is not yet established with primitive regulatory guidance available. Those who adopt the technology early will benefit from first mover advantage, enhanced data but may be hindered by ambiguous regulatory frameworks and thus heightened legal costs.
* Secondary market places are available for NFTs, however ensuring the market place is appropriate for insurance products may reuire a separate, better regulated market place. This external market infrastructure may take time to implement.
  Internal infrastructure will also take time and resources to implement. While products like Claimshare seamlessly integrate with existing systems, there may be other solutions that cause slightly more disruption to BAU activities.
* As is the case with any policy being booked, there is a risk of payments to scam insurance providers or suppliers - many company use approved supplier lists as a means of mitigating this risk. The NFTâ€™s provide the ability to verify the legitimacy of a contract. However a paying customer may not realise that the NFT they purchased was from an unverified collection and may complain upon arrival. The insurerâ€™s reputation may be on the line and hence a compromise may be required depending on the specific circumstances. Should there be some due diligence undertaken by the secondary market places? This would need to be established between the insurer and marketplace as part of the distribution agreement.

## Closing Remarks

Blockchain technology is already front of mind for many insurers with a significant number of Senior Executives ramping up their technology spend. The [Blockchain Insurance Industry Initiative (â€œB3iâ€)](https://b3i.tech/) has been growing since its inception in 2016, with 15 members collaborating to better understand the use case within the insurance industry.

While there is a key focus on blockchain tech generally, NFT use cases havenâ€™t yet been fully considered within the insurance sector. The new form of digital asset offers numerous beneficial properties and will inevitably permeate across multiple industries to varying degrees - it will be interesting to see how it offers solutions to existing industry challenges over the coming years.

To find out more, please visit our [website](https://originsnft.io/) or [Twitter](https://twitter.com/OriginsNFT?s=20&t=32UYETa5iiqxkDBj0NcVrg).

title: Applying NFTs: Insurance
body:
![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/eTUV2iycCqO3u2M4UEFr0.png?height=260&width=1378)

[Blockchain technology](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/b/blockchain.asp), and specifically [Non Fungible Tokens (â€œNFTsâ€)](https://www.investopedia.com/non-fungible-tokens-nft-5115211), are a relatively new form of technology. The initial use case of blockchain stemmed from the 2007 Global Financial Crisis (â€œGFCâ€) in the form of [Satoshi Nakamotoâ€™s Bitcoin whitepaper](https://nakamotoinstitute.org/bitcoin/). This subsequently went on to inspire several forks and new crypto currencies thus disrupting the traditional finance space during the 2017 [decentralized finance (â€œDefiâ€)](https://www.forbes.com/advisor/investing/cryptocurrency/defi-decentralized-finance/#:\~:text=%E2%80%9CDecentralized%20finance%20is%20an%20unbundling,the%20hands%20of%20regular%20people.%E2%80%9D) boom. Since then there have been new applications of the technology, but we are certainly early on in the road to mainstream adoption.

[Ethereum](https://ethereum.org/en/enterprise/) has smart contract functionality which is a key ingredient for the functionality of NFTs. While most of the utility is in the experimental stage, with a huge explosion in interest during 2021, it is inevitable that there will be disruption across all industries to varying degrees.

This article focuses on the use cases within the Insurance industry. First we will review the existing challenges in the industry before covering potential solutions from NFTs and blockchain technology.

## Industry Background

The insurance sector is a highly competitive, heavily regulated industry with consumer protection being a prime focus. The GFC, driven by mortgage loans and facilitated by most stakeholders in the financial system, meant legislators increased scrutiny to mitigate systemic risk and prevent future events recurring.

The impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic saw sizeable payouts for [business interruption](https://www.abi.org.uk/products-and-issues/topics-and-issues/coronavirus-hub/business-insurance/) insurance policies with astronomical liabilities being accrued as new legal precedents were set, following lengthy court cases. This caused a significant amount of stress on corporate balance sheets and large one off hits to their profit figures. According to [Mckinsey](https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/financial-services/our-insights/creating-value-finding-focus-global-insurance-report-2022), premium growth slowed (until last year) which would have exacerbated the issue and caused further adverse financial results.

![Source: Mckinsey](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/64OfK00OD0Lgnfn3mnWQQ.png?height=694&width=1636)

The industry incurs significant losses due to fraud. According to the [National Insurance Crime Bureau](https://www.nicb.org/news/news-releases/nicb-insurance-fraud-adds-billions-dollars-insurer-payouts-after-disasters#:\~:text=The%20NICB%20estimates%20disaster%20fraud,%246%20billion%20or%20about%207.5%25.), fraud adds five to 10 percent onto claims for disaster policies. The Pandemic caused a drop off in the number of frauds, predominantly due to restrictions on travel and the insurance products associated with this. While certain insurance products are more susceptible to fraud than others, it is certainly rife across the industry as a whole and expected to worsen as the cost of living rises thus increasing the statistical likelihood of consumers resorting to fraud to make ends meet. This is a large challenge in driving costs down, but the benefits can be passed onto customers in the form of reduced premiums should the costs be curtailed.

The systems used are archaic and cumbersome. According to [Capgemini](https://www.capgemini.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/Policy_Administration_Systems.pdf) â€œOver 60 percent of insurance providers find their policy administration systems out of date, expensive to run, inflexible and redundant. Market dynamics are forcing insurers to plot a course to replace these antiquated systemsâ€.

Insurers are constantly searching for ways of innovating to enhance IT infrastructure. According to the [Blackrock global insurance report](https://www.blackrock.com/institutions/en-ch/literature/whitepaper/global-insurance-report-2021.pdf), 59% of respondents (consisting of 362 senior executives across 26 markets) stated they intend to increase their technology spend on the previous year.

*In the next two years, how do you anticipate changing your spending/investment in your technology and infrastructure (compared with 2020 spend)?*

![Source: Blackrock](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/6mjBV9iybzbE-WqVCt4r6.png?height=808&width=1644)

Blockchain can boost transparency, aid better compliance with regulations, and build excellent products and markets. It can also drive a positive change in consumer behaviour to better benefit the wider society. We will now take a look at possible solutions available to some of these industry challenges.

## Industry Challenges & Blockchain / NFT Solutions

These solutions are general in nature and hence would need to be tailored to the specific type of insurance product offering, business model and size. The more complex listed insurers may require a more robust process which could take a longer lead time to implement when compared to a small insurance start-up which tends to be more agile.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/AurmCvpzmYNsnjHh9csk7.png?height=812&width=1430)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/YVBA_bb3bxp7FG6U7xPwr.png?height=1252&width=1432)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/KYIzbbU9q-l-P_vWNohTx.png?height=1388&width=1428)

## Real World Cases Studies

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/jA76iYs9U0Uqrs6mZtLSB.png?height=116&width=392)

1/ **[Nexus Mutual](https://nexusmutual.io/)** - Nexus Mutual uses the power of Ethereum so people can share risk together without the need for an insurance company. Areas the company look to cover include:

* Secure risk and potential bugs in smart contract code
* Be covered for events like DAO hacks or Parity multi-sig wallet issues
* Purchase Smart Contract Cover

While they are focusing on blockchain based cover, there are plans to expand to traditional types of insurance cover. The claim cover is put to a consensus vote as follows:

![Source: Nexus Mutual](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/bbzCYmnfC9BZPqRVU4czu.png?height=826&width=1226)

2/ Insurtech company, [Ryskex](https://ryskex.com/) helps provide insurers an easier way to assess and handle risks accurately through its blockchain-based platform.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wrw9RMuRTDitr2atMea_y.png?height=116&width=394)

According to [Ryskex](https://ryskex.com/) their platform *â€œallows a global network of leading investors to take on these hard to insure emerging and systemic risks. It also enables insureds to find the appropriate coverage using our parametric risk transfer solution and hedge their risks as securitised intangible assets, which can be traded transparently and securely using blockchain technology.â€*

This solution offers greater transparency for both insurers and insureds while keeping administration costs low.

3/ [Claimshare](https://claimshare.intellecteu.com/) - Insurers pay out duplicate claims for the same loss on countless occasions. The ClaimShare platform can detect and prevent â€œdouble-dippingâ€ across insurers without revealing any sensitive data. It is estimated that double dipping equates to $5-10 billion in fraud per year.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-IlanS4fRAOe9sxNIwYQa.png?height=140&width=372)

The platform integrates with existing insurance systems by using APIs, therefore a relatively seamless transition to using the new platform.

This diagram illustrates how the use of [Claimshare](https://claimshare.intellecteu.com/) amongst several insurers can prevent double dipping for the same claim:

![Source: Claimshare](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/RdqFSW6Jw-_TcAKBlx4va.png?height=864&width=1036)

## Risk Considerations

* While this new technology could lead to a competitive edge it will likely require a reasonable level of upfront investment so insurers would need to establish whether they would benefit from first mover advantage or if they are at a smaller scale could be better off delaying until the larger listed competitors have taken the plunge.
* Sharing the right amount of data to be transparent but not too much so that itâ€™s overwhelming. Competitive advantage may also be a consideration with regards to data being on the public blockchain.
* Education for all stakeholders involved may take time. Pitching the business proposal to investors for a budget to be approved for system implementation or providing guides for employees / policyholders on how to use the technology will consume company time and resources.
* Legal framework is not yet established with primitive regulatory guidance available. Those who adopt the technology early will benefit from first mover advantage, enhanced data but may be hindered by ambiguous regulatory frameworks and thus heightened legal costs.
* Secondary market places are available for NFTs, however ensuring the market place is appropriate for insurance products may reuire a separate, better regulated market place. This external market infrastructure may take time to implement.
  Internal infrastructure will also take time and resources to implement. While products like Claimshare seamlessly integrate with existing systems, there may be other solutions that cause slightly more disruption to BAU activities.
* As is the case with any policy being booked, there is a risk of payments to scam insurance providers or suppliers - many company use approved supplier lists as a means of mitigating this risk. The NFTâ€™s provide the ability to verify the legitimacy of a contract. However a paying customer may not realise that the NFT they purchased was from an unverified collection and may complain upon arrival. The insurerâ€™s reputation may be on the line and hence a compromise may be required depending on the specific circumstances. Should there be some due diligence undertaken by the secondary market places? This would need to be established between the insurer and marketplace as part of the distribution agreement.

## Closing Remarks

Blockchain technology is already front of mind for many insurers with a significant number of Senior Executives ramping up their technology spend. The [Blockchain Insurance Industry Initiative (â€œB3iâ€)](https://b3i.tech/) has been growing since its inception in 2016, with 15 members collaborating to better understand the use case within the insurance industry.

While there is a key focus on blockchain tech generally, NFT use cases havenâ€™t yet been fully considered within the insurance sector. The new form of digital asset offers numerous beneficial properties and will inevitably permeate across multiple industries to varying degrees - it will be interesting to see how it offers solutions to existing industry challenges over the coming years.

At [OriginsNFT](https://originsnft.io/) we leverage data-driven decision making, educational resources, and proprietary analytics to remain ahead of the curve with respect to blockchain tech and specifically NFTs. To find out more, please visit our [website](https://originsnft.io/) or [Twitter](https://twitter.com/OriginsNFT?s=20&t=32UYETa5iiqxkDBj0NcVrg).

To purchase a pass, please visit our [Opensea page](https://opensea.io/assets/ethereum/0x495f947276749ce646f68ac8c248420045cb7b5e/63763212585141476199723449601564140078511354041472126739157516503384422613942).

title: Applying NFTs: Insurance
body:
![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/eTUV2iycCqO3u2M4UEFr0.png?height=260&width=1378)

[Blockchain technology](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/b/blockchain.asp), and specifically [Non Fungible Tokens (â€œNFTsâ€)](https://www.investopedia.com/non-fungible-tokens-nft-5115211), are a relatively new form of technology. The initial use case of blockchain stemmed from the 2007 Global Financial Crisis (â€œGFCâ€) in the form of [Satoshi Nakamotoâ€™s Bitcoin whitepaper](https://nakamotoinstitute.org/bitcoin/). This subsequently went on to inspire several forks and new crypto currencies thus disrupting the traditional finance space during the 2017 [decentralized finance (â€œDefiâ€)](https://www.forbes.com/advisor/investing/cryptocurrency/defi-decentralized-finance/#:\~:text=%E2%80%9CDecentralized%20finance%20is%20an%20unbundling,the%20hands%20of%20regular%20people.%E2%80%9D) boom. Since then there have been new applications of the technology, but we are certainly early on in the road to mainstream adoption.

[Ethereum](https://ethereum.org/en/enterprise/) has smart contract functionality which is a key ingredient for the functionality of NFTs. While most of the utility is in the experimental stage, with a huge explosion in interest during 2021, it is inevitable that there will be disruption across all industries to varying degrees.

This article focuses on the use cases within the Insurance industry. First we will review the existing challenges in the industry before covering potential solutions from NFTs and blockchain technology.

## Industry Background

The insurance sector is a highly competitive, heavily regulated industry with consumer protection being a prime focus. The GFC, driven by mortgage loans and facilitated by most stakeholders in the financial system, meant legislators increased scrutiny to mitigate systemic risk and prevent future events recurring.

The impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic saw sizeable payouts for [business interruption](https://www.abi.org.uk/products-and-issues/topics-and-issues/coronavirus-hub/business-insurance/) insurance policies with astronomical liabilities being accrued as new legal precedents were set, following lengthy court cases. This caused a significant amount of stress on corporate balance sheets and large one off hits to their profit figures. According to [Mckinsey](https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/financial-services/our-insights/creating-value-finding-focus-global-insurance-report-2022), premium growth slowed (until last year) which would have exacerbated the issue and caused further adverse financial results.

![Source: Mckinsey](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/64OfK00OD0Lgnfn3mnWQQ.png?height=694&width=1636)

The industry incurs significant losses due to fraud. According to the [National Insurance Crime Bureau](https://www.nicb.org/news/news-releases/nicb-insurance-fraud-adds-billions-dollars-insurer-payouts-after-disasters#:\~:text=The%20NICB%20estimates%20disaster%20fraud,%246%20billion%20or%20about%207.5%25.), fraud adds five to 10 percent onto claims for disaster policies. The Pandemic caused a drop off in the number of frauds, predominantly due to restrictions on travel and the insurance products associated with this. While certain insurance products are more susceptible to fraud than others, it is certainly rife across the industry as a whole and expected to worsen as the cost of living rises thus increasing the statistical likelihood of consumers resorting to fraud to make ends meet. This is a large challenge in driving costs down, but the benefits can be passed onto customers in the form of reduced premiums should the costs be curtailed.

The systems used are archaic and cumbersome. According to [Capgemini](https://www.capgemini.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/Policy_Administration_Systems.pdf) â€œOver 60 percent of insurance providers find their policy administration systems out of date, expensive to run, inflexible and redundant. Market dynamics are forcing insurers to plot a course to replace these antiquated systemsâ€.

Insurers are constantly searching for ways of innovating to enhance IT infrastructure. According to the [Blackrock global insurance report](https://www.blackrock.com/institutions/en-ch/literature/whitepaper/global-insurance-report-2021.pdf), 59% of respondents (consisting of 362 senior executives across 26 markets) stated they intend to increase their technology spend on the previous year.

*In the next two years, how do you anticipate changing your spending/investment in your technology and infrastructure (compared with 2020 spend)?*

![Source: Blackrock](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/6mjBV9iybzbE-WqVCt4r6.png?height=808&width=1644)

Blockchain can boost transparency, aid better compliance with regulations, and build excellent products and markets. It can also drive a positive change in consumer behaviour to better benefit the wider society. We will now take a look at possible solutions available to some of these industry challenges.

## Industry Challenges & Blockchain / NFT Solutions

These solutions are general in nature and hence would need to be tailored to the specific type of insurance product offering, business model and size. The more complex listed insurers may require a more robust process which could take a longer lead time to implement when compared to a small insurance start-up which tends to be more agile.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/AurmCvpzmYNsnjHh9csk7.png?height=812&width=1430)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/YVBA_bb3bxp7FG6U7xPwr.png?height=1252&width=1432)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/KYIzbbU9q-l-P_vWNohTx.png?height=1388&width=1428)

## Real World Cases Studies

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/jA76iYs9U0Uqrs6mZtLSB.png?height=116&width=392)

1/ **[Nexus Mutual](https://nexusmutual.io/)** - Nexus Mutual uses the power of Ethereum so people can share risk together without the need for an insurance company. Areas the company look to cover include:

* Secure risk and potential bugs in smart contract code
* Be covered for events like DAO hacks or Parity multi-sig wallet issues
* Purchase Smart Contract Cover

While they are focusing on blockchain based cover, there are plans to expand to traditional types of insurance cover. The claim cover is put to a consensus vote as follows:

![Source: Nexus Mutual](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/bbzCYmnfC9BZPqRVU4czu.png?height=826&width=1226)

2/ Insurtech company, [Ryskex](https://ryskex.com/) helps provide insurers an easier way to assess and handle risks accurately through its blockchain-based platform.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wrw9RMuRTDitr2atMea_y.png?height=116&width=394)

According to [Ryskex](https://ryskex.com/) their platform *â€œallows a global network of leading investors to take on these hard to insure emerging and systemic risks. It also enables insureds to find the appropriate coverage using our parametric risk transfer solution and hedge their risks as securitised intangible assets, which can be traded transparently and securely using blockchain technology.â€*

This solution offers greater transparency for both insurers and insureds while keeping administration costs low.

3/ [Claimshare](https://claimshare.intellecteu.com/) - Insurers pay out duplicate claims for the same loss on countless occasions. The ClaimShare platform can detect and prevent â€œdouble-dippingâ€ across insurers without revealing any sensitive data. It is estimated that double dipping equates to $5-10 billion in fraud per year.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-IlanS4fRAOe9sxNIwYQa.png?height=140&width=372)

The platform integrates with existing insurance systems by using APIs, therefore a relatively seamless transition to using the new platform.

This diagram illustrates how the use of [Claimshare](https://claimshare.intellecteu.com/) amongst several insurers can prevent double dipping for the same claim:

![Source: Claimshare](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/RdqFSW6Jw-_TcAKBlx4va.png?height=864&width=1036)

## Risk Considerations

* While this new technology could lead to a competitive edge it will likely require a reasonable level of upfront investment so insurers would need to establish whether they would benefit from first mover advantage or if they are at a smaller scale could be better off delaying until the larger listed competitors have taken the plunge.
* Sharing the right amount of data to be transparent but not too much so that itâ€™s overwhelming. Competitive advantage may also be a consideration with regards to data being on the public blockchain.
* Education for all stakeholders involved may take time. Pitching the business proposal to investors for a budget to be approved for system implementation or providing guides for employees / policyholders on how to use the technology will consume company time and resources.
* Legal framework is not yet established with primitive regulatory guidance available. Those who adopt the technology early will benefit from first mover advantage, enhanced data but may be hindered by ambiguous regulatory frameworks and thus heightened legal costs.
* Secondary market places are available for NFTs, however ensuring the market place is appropriate for insurance products may reuire a separate, better regulated market place. This external market infrastructure may take time to implement.
  Internal infrastructure will also take time and resources to implement. While products like Claimshare seamlessly integrate with existing systems, there may be other solutions that cause slightly more disruption to BAU activities.
* As is the case with any policy being booked, there is a risk of payments to scam insurance providers or suppliers - many company use approved supplier lists as a means of mitigating this risk. The NFTâ€™s provide the ability to verify the legitimacy of a contract. However a paying customer may not realise that the NFT they purchased was from an unverified collection and may complain upon arrival. The insurerâ€™s reputation may be on the line and hence a compromise may be required depending on the specific circumstances. Should there be some due diligence undertaken by the secondary market places? This would need to be established between the insurer and marketplace as part of the distribution agreement.

## Closing Remarks

Blockchain technology is already front of mind for many insurers with a significant number of Senior Executives ramping up their technology spend. The [Blockchain Insurance Industry Initiative (â€œB3iâ€)](https://b3i.tech/) has been growing since its inception in 2016, with 15 members collaborating to better understand the use case within the insurance industry.

While there is a key focus on blockchain tech generally, NFT use cases havenâ€™t yet been fully considered within the insurance sector. The new form of digital asset offers numerous beneficial properties and will inevitably permeate across multiple industries to varying degrees - it will be interesting to see how it offers solutions to existing industry challenges over the coming years.

At [OriginsNFT](https://originsnft.io/) we leverage data-driven decision making, educational resources, and proprietary analytics to remain ahead of the curve with respect to blockchain tech and specifically NFTs. To find out more, please visit our [website](https://originsnft.io/) or [Twitter](https://twitter.com/OriginsNFT?s=20&t=32UYETa5iiqxkDBj0NcVrg).

To purchase a pass, please visit our [Opensea page](https://opensea.io/assets/ethereum/0x495f947276749ce646f68ac8c248420045cb7b5e/63763212585141476199723449601564140078511354041472126739157516503384422613942).

![Source: Blackrock](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/6mjBV9iybzbE-WqVCt4r6.png?height=808&width=1644)

Blockchain can boost transparency, aid better compliance with regulations, and build excellent products and markets. It can also drive a positive change in consumer behaviour to better benefit the wider society. We will now take a look at possible solutions available to some of these industry challenges.

## Industry Challenges & Blockchain / NFT Solutions

These solutions are general in nature and hence would need to be tailored to the specific type of insurance product offering, business model and size. The more complex listed insurers may require a more robust process which could take a longer lead time to implement when compared to a small insurance start-up which tends to be more agile.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/AurmCvpzmYNsnjHh9csk7.png?height=812&width=1430)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/YVBA_bb3bxp7FG6U7xPwr.png?height=1252&width=1432)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/KYIzbbU9q-l-P_vWNohTx.png?height=1388&width=1428)

## Real World Cases Studies

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/jA76iYs9U0Uqrs6mZtLSB.png?height=116&width=392)

1/ **[Nexus Mutual](https://nexusmutual.io/)** - Nexus Mutual uses the power of Ethereum so people can share risk together without the need for an insurance company. Areas the company look to cover include:

* Secure risk and potential bugs in smart contract code
* Be covered for events like DAO hacks or Parity multi-sig wallet issues
* Purchase Smart Contract Cover

While they are focusing on blockchain based cover, there are plans to expand to traditional types of insurance cover. The claim cover is put to a consensus vote as follows:

![Source: Nexus Mutual](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/bbzCYmnfC9BZPqRVU4czu.png?height=826&width=1226)

2/ Insurtech company, [Ryskex](https://ryskex.com/) helps provide insurers an easier way to assess and handle risks accurately through its blockchain-based platform.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wrw9RMuRTDitr2atMea_y.png?height=116&width=394)

According to [Ryskex](https://ryskex.com/) their platform *â€œallows a global network of leading investors to take on these hard to insure emerging and systemic risks. It also enables insureds to find the appropriate coverage using our parametric risk transfer solution and hedge their risks as securitised intangible assets, which can be traded transparently and securely using blockchain technology.â€*

This solution offers greater transparency for both insurers and insureds while keeping administration costs low.

3/ [Claimshare](https://claimshare.intellecteu.com/) - Insurers pay out duplicate claims for the same loss on countless occasions. The ClaimShare platform can detect and prevent â€œdouble-dippingâ€ across insurers without revealing any sensitive data. It is estimated that double dipping equates to $5-10 billion in fraud per year.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-IlanS4fRAOe9sxNIwYQa.png?height=140&width=372)

The platform integrates with existing insurance systems by using APIs, therefore a relatively seamless transition to using the new platform.

This diagram illustrates how the use of [Claimshare](https://claimshare.intellecteu.com/) amongst several insurers can prevent double dipping for the same claim:

![Source: Claimshare](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/RdqFSW6Jw-_TcAKBlx4va.png?height=864&width=1036)

## Risk Considerations

* While this new technology could lead to a competitive edge it will likely require a reasonable level of upfront investment so insurers would need to establish whether they would benefit from first mover advantage or if they are at a smaller scale could be better off delaying until the larger listed competitors have taken the plunge.
* Sharing the right amount of data to be transparent but not too much so that itâ€™s overwhelming. Competitive advantage may also be a consideration with regards to data being on the public blockchain.
* Education for all stakeholders involved may take time. Pitching the business proposal to investors for a budget to be approved for system implementation or providing guides for employees / policyholders on how to use the technology will consume company time and resources.
* Legal framework is not yet established with primitive regulatory guidance available. Those who adopt the technology early will benefit from first mover advantage, enhanced data but may be hindered by ambiguous regulatory frameworks and thus heightened legal costs.
* Secondary market places are available for NFTs, however ensuring the market place is appropriate for insurance products may reuire a separate, better regulated market place. This external market infrastructure may take time to implement.
  Internal infrastructure will also take time and resources to implement. While products like Claimshare seamlessly integrate with existing systems, there may be other solutions that cause slightly more disruption to BAU activities.
* As is the case with any policy being booked, there is a risk of payments to scam insurance providers or suppliers - many company use approved supplier lists as a means of mitigating this risk. The NFTâ€™s provide the ability to verify the legitimacy of a contract. However a paying customer may not realise that the NFT they purchased was from an unverified collection and may complain upon arrival. The insurerâ€™s reputation may be on the line and hence a compromise may be required depending on the specific circumstances. Should there be some due diligence undertaken by the secondary market places? This would need to be established between the insurer and marketplace as part of the distribution agreement.

## Closing Remarks

Blockchain technology is already front of mind for many insurers with a significant number of Senior Executives ramping up their technology spend. The [Blockchain Insurance Industry Initiative (â€œB3iâ€)](https://b3i.tech/) has been growing since its inception in 2016, with 15 members collaborating to better understand the use case within the insurance industry.

While there is a key focus on blockchain tech generally, NFT use cases havenâ€™t yet been fully considered within the insurance sector. The new form of digital asset offers numerous beneficial properties and will inevitably permeate across multiple industries to varying degrees - it will be interesting to see how it offers solutions to existing industry challenges over the coming years.

At [OriginsNFT](https://originsnft.io/) we leverage data-driven decision making, educational resources, and proprietary analytics to remain ahead of the curve with respect to blockchain tech and specifically NFTs. To find out more, please visit our [website](https://originsnft.io/) or [Twitter](https://twitter.com/OriginsNFT?s=20&t=32UYETa5iiqxkDBj0NcVrg).

To purchase a pass, please visit our [Opensea page](https://opensea.io/assets/ethereum/0x495f947276749ce646f68ac8c248420045cb7b5e/63763212585141476199723449601564140078511354041472126739157516503384422613942).

title: Default Humans
body:
**THE ORIGIN**

The idea of Default Humans only came around to be when there was an increasing trend of NFTs in social avatar collections. Do you use social media a lot and often find yourself rarely having a proper social avatar to go along with your socials? (Twitter, Instagram, etc.)

That is where the idea of Default Humans emerged. Solely for the NFT bums, with the base avatar as only the Default Human icon, *like most social media have when you first create an account*;

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/5NRBPTg8k2GgXFa69jYdN.png?height=1300&width=1600)

We have made use of our creativity to turn the icon into something more human-like, into Default Humans. We wanted this project to be simple, nothing more than your typical copy/paste roadmap, basic â€œutilityâ€ bullsh\*t, and live up to its reputation of it being â€œjust jpegsâ€.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Qk6nHSCdUDokCGjt-0Aba.png?height=1416&width=2557)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-ZeCxcQ-PXg-lW4nqIT7f.jpg?height=1526&width=2835)

***3. The Art*** ğŸ–¼

Default Humans is a cartoony, goofy-like representation of Humans that reside in the ecosystem of the Polygon network. Other collections may followâ€¦

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/IPXOZ1oacjaMhFVFkYsyZ.png?height=800&width=1200)

***4. Full Commercial Rights*** ğŸ‘

You own all commercial rights to the images of all your Humans, including the right to make copies of, distribute, and otherwise commercially exploit the images, for any purpose.

***5. Solely for the NFT bums*** ğŸ™Š

Weâ€™re just hopping on the NFT bandwagon because we can, and because we believe we have what it takes to release a genuine collection, no matter the outcome. Default Humans NFT is not for everyone, and thatâ€™s what makes it special. If youâ€™re looking for something more serious, go look at Bored Ape. Or not, we donâ€™t care.

### Frequently Asked Questions

* **Why Default Humans?**
  * Solely for the NFT bums. If youâ€™re looking for something more serious, go look at Bored Ape. Or not, we donâ€™t care.

  * We donâ€™t believe in having utility if thereâ€™s no plans in the foreseeable future. Unlike many projects who promise utility and fail to deliver at times, we promise very little. 
* **How many NFTs will there be?**
  * A small collection of 500 Default Humans will be created and minted on the Polygon blockchain.
* **How much to mint a Human?**
  * Humans will be listed at 0.015 ETH per mint.
* **Will there be Whitelisting?**
  * There will be NO WHITELIST! All Humans will be publicly minted. All is equal.

  * No roadmap.

title: Crypto correction creating 'opportunity in the market,' Binance CEO says
body:
Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao joins Yahoo Finance Live to discuss the bear market in crypto, buying opportunities, as well as the outlook for bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies.

### Video Transcript

BRAD SMITH: Everyone, we're going to switch gears for a hot second here as we take a brief look here at the crypto markets-- Binance, Bitcoin, you've got to look at that on your screen. And volatility has reared its ugly head once again seriously impacting the value of many crypto firms. This leaves us wondering when and if someone will be there to bail out any sinking projects.

For more, let's welcome in Changpeng Zhao, who is the Binance CEO, as well as Yahoo Finance's David Hollerith. CZ-- hope I can call you CZ-- thanks so much for joining us here today. First and foremost, just help us break down what you're seeing in the crypto landscape-- the washing out that we've discussed here-- and when some of that within this crypto winter will start to settle, you believe.

CHANGPENG ZHAO: Yeah. So we're definitely seeing some a correction, or a downturn, or bear market, however you call it. Different people have different terms for it. So yeah, we dropped from the all-time high from $68K per Bitcoin to 20-something-- $21K per Bitcoin right now.

And we're seeing that a number of firms are insolvent and a number of projects have gone under. But it's a small number in the grand scheme of things. So markets do go in cycles, even stock markets-- especially stock markets-- go in cycles as well. So we actually see a lot of opportunity in the market.

So we're increasing our hiring, increasing our M&A activities. We're looking at lowering fees on our platforms so that we make it easier for our users during this period.

DAVID HOLLERITH: CZ, David Hollerith here. Thanks for coming on the show. You know, Sam Bankman-Fried, the Founder and CEO of FTX, has sort of come out right now, notably, for bailing out some of these crypto firms that have run into trouble. I follow your Twitter and I know you're extensively keeping track of firms that are pausing withdrawals. title: Default Humans
body:
**THE ORIGIN**

The idea of Default Humans only came around to be when there was an increasing trend of NFTs in social avatar collections. Do you use social media a lot and often find yourself rarely having a proper social avatar to go along with your socials? (Twitter, Instagram, etc.)

That is where the idea of Default Humans emerged. Solely for the NFT bums, with the base avatar as only the Default Human icon, *like most social media have when you first create an account*;

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/5NRBPTg8k2GgXFa69jYdN.png?height=1300&width=1600)

We have made use of our creativity to turn the icon into something more human-like, into Default Humans. We wanted this project to be simple, nothing more than your typical copy/paste roadmap, basic â€œutilityâ€ bullsh\*t, and live up to its reputation of it being â€œjust jpegsâ€.

**THE BENEFITS**

***1. Charitable Project*** ğŸ’™ğŸ«‚

Even if this is a simple project, we still have goals and there are still benefits in holding a Human. We are a simple, but also a charitable project; Default Humans aims to give 20% of our profits to UNICEF in doing whatever it takes to save and protect the worldâ€™s most vulnerable children.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Qk6nHSCdUDokCGjt-0Aba.png?height=1416&width=2557)

***2. Exclusive Merch*** ğŸ‘•

Gain exclusive access to our upcoming merch store while holding a Human! Only holders of the Default Humans NFT can purchase merch, including hoodies, t-shirts, hats & more!

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-ZeCxcQ-PXg-lW4nqIT7f.jpg?height=1526&width=2835)

***3. The Art*** ğŸ–¼

Default Humans is a cartoony, goofy-like representation of Humans that reside in the ecosystem of the Polygon network. Other collections may followâ€¦

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/IPXOZ1oacjaMhFVFkYsyZ.png?height=800&width=1200)

***4. Full Commercial Rights*** ğŸ‘

You own all commercial rights to the images of all your Humans, including the right to make copies of, distribute, and otherwise commercially exploit the images, for any purpose.

***5. Solely for the NFT bums*** ğŸ™Š

Weâ€™re just hopping on the NFT bandwagon because we can, and because we believe we have what it takes to release a genuine collection, no matter the outcome. Default Humans NFT is not for everyone, and thatâ€™s what makes it special. If youâ€™re looking for something more serious, go look at Bored Ape. Or not, we donâ€™t care.

### Frequently Asked Questions

* **Why Default Humans?**
  * Solely for the NFT bums. If youâ€™re looking for something more serious, go look at Bored Ape. Or not, we donâ€™t care.
* **Why does your project not have much utility?**
  * We donâ€™t believe in having utility if thereâ€™s no plans in the foreseeable future. Unlike many projects who promise utility and fail to deliver at times, we promise very little.
* **How many NFTs will there be?**
  * A small collection of 500 Default Humans will be created and minted on the Polygon blockchain.
* **How much to mint a Human?**
  * Humans will be listed at 0.015 ETH per mint.
* **Will there be Whitelisting?**
  * There will be NO WHITELIST! All Humans will be publicly minted. All is equal.
* **â€œYou need a discord! >:(â€œ**
  * No we donâ€™t.
* **Roadmap?**
  * No roadmap.

title: Yuga Labs files lawsuit claiming Bored Ape Yacht Club NFT 'copycats'
body:
Yuga Labs, creators of Bored Ape Yacht Club Non-Fungible Tokens (NFTs), has sued artist Ryder Ripps and several associates, accusing them of producing and selling â€œcopycat NFTsâ€ that devalue the originals, according to its [Twitter feed](https://twitter.com/yugalabs/status/1540509851641692160) and that of the Bored Ape Gazette, which [tweeted](https://twitter.com/BoredApeGazette/status/1540562304852529152) a lawsuit filing with inserted illustrations.

The lawsuit claims that the artist sought to â€œdevalue the Bored Ape NFTs by flooding the NFT market with his own copycat NFT collection using the original Bored Ape Yacht Club images and calling them â€œRR/BAYCâ€ NFTs.â€

The suit points out that Bored Ape NFTs â€œoften resell for hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of dollars, and prominent celebrities are proud holders of Bored Ape NFTs,â€ adding that only 10,000 Bored Ape NFTs exist and that each is unique.

Yuga Labs seeks a judgement restraining Ripps and associates from â€œengaging in further interference with its prospective economic relations,â€ as well as damages and attorneysâ€™ fees.

An email seeking comment on the lawsuit from Ripps was sent to an address on his website, but no response had been received by time of publication.

title: Yuga Labs files lawsuit claiming Bored Ape Yacht Club NFT 'copycats'
body:
Yuga Labs, creators of Bored Ape Yacht Club Non-Fungible Tokens (NFTs), has sued artist Ryder Ripps and several associates, accusing them of producing and selling â€œcopycat NFTsâ€ that devalue the originals, according to its [Twitter feed](https://twitter.com/yugalabs/status/1540509851641692160) and that of the Bored Ape Gazette, which [tweeted](https://twitter.com/BoredApeGazette/status/1540562304852529152) a lawsuit filing with inserted illustrations.

The lawsuit claims that the artist sought to â€œdevalue the Bored Ape NFTs by flooding the NFT market with his own copycat NFT collection using the original Bored Ape Yacht Club images and calling them â€œRR/BAYCâ€ NFTs.â€

The suit points out that Bored Ape NFTs â€œoften resell for hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of dollars, and prominent celebrities are proud holders of Bored Ape NFTs,â€ adding that only 10,000 Bored Ape NFTs exist and that each is unique.

Yuga Labs seeks a judgement restraining Ripps and associates from â€œengaging in further interference with its prospective economic relations,â€ as well as damages and attorneysâ€™ fees.

An email seeking comment on the lawsuit from Ripps was sent to an address on his website, but no response had been received by time of publication.

Ripps said earlier this year on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/ryder_ripps/status/1491165111813558273) that he had been â€œresearching and posting about BAYC Nazi ties.â€ The Bored Ape founders [pushed back](https://www.theblock.co/post/154094/bored-ape-founders-push-back-on-nazi-accusations-open-up-about-logo-inspiration) against these allegations in a blog post on Friday.

title: Former Crypto Billionaire Insists Bitcoin Will Soar To $250,000 Within Next 18 Months
body:
## Venture capitalist Tim Draper thinks cryptocurrency is going to go up more than 10-fold by the end of 2023. He isnâ€™t the only crypto mogul whistling in the dark.


---

During an interview with *Forbes* in January this year, the venture capitalist Tim Draper offered an ambitious prediction: Bitcoin would hit a whopping $250,000 within a year. At the time, Bitcoin was worth about $41,000.

â€œThis is the year it's gonna happen,â€ insisted Draper, who paid $18.7 million at a U.S. Marshals Service auction in 2014 for his stash of around 30,000 bitcoins (yes, thatâ€™s $623 per Bitcoin). â€œBy the end of this yearâ€”or early next year.â€

Suffice it to say that Draperâ€™s prediction isnâ€™t panning out. Bitcoin has lost more than half of its value since the start of the year, plunging from $47,000 on New Yearâ€™s day to around $20,000. He is one of four crypto moguls who are no longer billionaires thanks to the digital currency crash. But Draper isnâ€™t backing off. Reached over email, Draper reiterated his price target. â€œI am more convinced than ever that it is happening,â€ he said. â€œBy late 2022 or early 2023.â€


---

## Easy Come, Easy Go

*Since early March, these eleven people have lost the most money in cryptoâ€”an aggregate of $61 billion over the last three months. Only seven are still billionaires.*


---

Fred Ehrsam, cofounder and former president of crypto exchange Coinbase, insists the market meltdown is nothing more than growing pains. â€œOne thing most people don't fully grasp: it takes years, often decades, to go from a new infrastructure-level technology breakthrough (like crypto) to a vibrant ecosystem of mainstream applications,â€ [tweeted](https://twitter.com/FEhrsam/status/1538971042072477696) Ehrsam earlier this week. The 34-year-old computer whiz is now worth an estimated $900 million, down from $2.1 billion in March.

One reason Ehrsam may have a cool head: His fortune includes around $367 million in post-tax cash proceeds from sales of Coinbase stock, which he unloaded last year at an average price of $316 a share (Coinbase is currently trading at about $52 per share). Ehrsam seems to see the market collapse as a buying opportunity: He bought $77 million of Coinbase stock on behalf of his crypto venture capital and investment firm, Paradigm Capital, in May, for between $60 and $73 per share.

Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss, the Bitcoin investors, twin brothers and founders of crypto trading firm Gemini, have also seen their fortunes fall, from an estimated $4 billion in March to $3.2 billion now. They laid off 10% of Geminiâ€™s staff on June 2, [citing](https://www.gemini.com/blog/a-message-from-cameron-and-tyler) the â€œcrypto winter.â€ But they havenâ€™t let the market implosion cramp their style. Their throwback rock band, [Mars Junction](https://twitter.com/MarsJunction?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor), is currently on tour in California and in early June, the twins were [videotaped at a bar in Asbury Park, New Jersey singing](https://twitter.com/arch_nem/status/1535102592270929930?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1535102592270929930%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fnypost.com%2F2022%2F06%2F13%2Fwinklevoss-twins-cover-dont-stop-believin-days-after-laying-off-crypto-employees%2F) Journeyâ€™s Donâ€™t Stop Believinâ€™ about a week after theyâ€™d announced Geminiâ€™s layoffs. As of press time, tickets for Mars Junctionâ€™s show in Berkeley tonight are $15 each.

While the Winklevoss twins are playing rock star, Sam Bankman-Fried, the richest person in crypto, is going for a different role: Industry Savior. Earlier this week, the mop-headed 30-year-old founder of trading juggernaut FTX extended huge loans to embattled crypto companies: $250 million to crypto lender BlockFi and nearly $500 million (including $300 million in Bitcoin, of course) to brokerage Voyager Digital. â€œWe take our duty seriously to protect the digital asset ecosystem and its customers,â€ he [tweeted](https://twitter.com/SBF_FTX/status/1539268638791696385). Bankman-Friedâ€™s estimated fortune has only dipped a few billion dollars since March, from $24 billion to $20 billion, mostly thanks to FTXâ€™s [$32 billion valuation](https://www.forbes.com/sites/jonathanponciano/2022/01/31/billionaire-bankman-frieds-crypto-exchange-ftx-lands-32-billion-valuation-and-400-million-in-new-funding/?sh=2af4e414305f) from its last funding round in January.

title: Fullvoting
body:
Fullvoting is an idea to combine **direct, representative and augmented voting for DAOs**.

Why?

1. To make better decisions
2. To increase the number of people who can effectively collaborate in decentralized organisations

Many DAOs such as ENS, BitDAO, Decentraland, Proof of Humanity and Uniswap use [Snapshot](http://snapshot.org) for off-chain voting.

These DAOs choose one or more [voting strategies](https://docs.snapshot.org/strategies/what-is-a-strategy) on Snapshot.

A voting strategy on Snapshot that would enable direct+representative+augmented voting would allow eth addresses to delegate to a URL. E.g. my-voting-provider.com/user

Then, the js code of the strategy would fetch something like my-voting-provider.com/user/space/proposal to know a vote.

These voting URLs would have no authentication. Anyone could see on my-voting-provider.com/USER/space/proposal would see the vote of the representative USER.

These URL voting providers are composable.

For example, provider1.com/BLUE could delegate to the following list:

1. provider1.com/A
2. provider1.com/B
3. provider2.com/C

In the previous example, provider1 could also let BLUE vote directly.

So if BLUE doesn't vote but A does, BLUE would vote as A regardless of B and C. If BLUE and A don't vote but B does, BLUE would vote as B regardless of C. But if B doesn't vote either, do as C says.

Consider that BLUE, A and B are from the same URL voting provider, but C doesn't.

This means that A and B can use delegation list + override like BLUE. But C, the last delegate from BLUE, is on a completely different provider.

This other URL voting provider could allow C to delegate to a list of all Nobel laureates or MIT neuroscientists. This provider could integrate with Wikidata/Wikipedia to confirm their occupation, alma mater and awards â€” like my old side project [agreelist.org](http://agreelist.org/)

Or this URL voting provider could be a16z which [already delegates half of their voting tokens](https://a16z.com/2021/08/26/open-sourcing-our-token-delegate-program).

Or one of the delegates on the URL voting provider could be AI-assisted or completely autonomous like [CÃ©sar Hidalgoâ€™s augmented democracy TED talk](https://www.ted.com/talks/cesar_hidalgo_a_bold_idea_to_replace_politicians).

To mitigate risks, delegations could end a few days before the direct voting.

And your URL voting provider could end AI-assisted delegates before human delegates.

That way people could always be alerted and override votes from delegates.

If we wish to enhance security, when an off-chain fullvoting period ends, we could have a period of time to get on-chain signatures. If enough signatures are gathered, the decision would be voted via on-chain direct voting. This would be similar to Switzerlandâ€™s referendums where citizens ratify laws approved by politicians in a referendum if they gather enough signatures.

To sum up, if we implement direct+representative+augmented voting for DAOs we could:

1. Make better decisions
2. Increase the number of people who can effectively collaborate in decentralized organisations

And this is important because of what the MIT Professor Alex Pentland said:

> *The biggest problem in the world is not climate change, war or poverty, but how we organise among ourselves to make good decisions and carry them out.*

What do you think? Does it make sense? Should we build this?

If you think it is worth exploring, please reach me at [@arpahector](https://twitter.com/arpahector) or leave your email on [fullvoting.org](https://fullvoting.org/):

[https://fullvoting.org/](https://fullvoting.org/)

Originally published on [June 21, 2022](https://twitter.com/arpahector/status/1539179369717022720)

title: Morgan Creek Is Trying to Counter FTXâ€™s BlockFi Bailout, Leaked Call Shows
body:
Cryptocurrency investment firm Morgan Creek Digital is attempting to raise $250 million from investors to purchase a majority stake in crypto lender BlockFi, a leaked investor call from Tuesday reveals.

Morgan Creekâ€™s plan to rapidly assemble an equity offer was hatched in response to crypto exchange FTXâ€™s Tuesday morning announcement that it would extend a [$250 million credit line](https://www.coindesk.com/business/2022/06/21/blockfi-receives-250m-credit-facility-from-ftx/) to BlockFi.

Morgan Creek Digital declined to comment. A person with knowledge of the effort said there are multiple venture capital funds that are exploring ways to provide equity financing to BlockFi as the lender struggles to stay afloat.

At stake is the ability of BlockFiâ€™s existing shareholders, including longtime backer Morgan Creek, to recoup their investments.

â€œIâ€™ve been making calls all day,â€ Morgan Creek Digital managing partner Mark Yusko said on the leaked call.

According to Yusko, the FTX credit line proposal had a catch for BlockFiâ€™s existing shareholders: It gave FTX the option to buy BlockFi â€œat essentially zero price.â€ If FTX were to exercise said option, it would effectively wipe out all of BlockFiâ€™s existing equity shareholders, including management and employees with stock options, as well as all equity investors in the companyâ€™s previous venture rounds.

However, Yusko said on the leaked call that BlockFi founders Zac Prince and Flori Marquez had a valid reason for preliminarily accepting the terms: Of the several emergency financing offers BlockFi received, FTXâ€™s was the only one that would not subordinate client assets to the rescuer.

In other words, unless BlockFi went with FTX, its depositors would have had to wait in line behind the new lender to be repaid. Additionally, BlockFi had not received any equity financing options at that stage. (Yusko did not identify any of the other firms that proposed bailout packages for BlockFi.)

***Read more: [BlockFi Receives $250M Credit Facility From FTX](https://www.coindesk.com/business/2022/06/21/blockfi-receives-250m-credit-facility-from-ftx/)***

BlockFi CEO Prince [tweeted](https://twitter.com/BlockFiZac/status/1539216594383028224?s=20&t=Xm_oJsv2PjecTEKO6SUlJA) on June 21 that the company had signed a preliminary term sheet with FTX. Yusko told investors on the leaked call that day that FTX and BlockFi were â€œprobably three days away from signing a definitive agreement.â€

â€œWe are still negotiating the terms of the deal and cannot share more information at this time,â€ a BlockFi spokesperson told CoinDesk on Saturday. â€œWe anticipate sharing more on the terms of the deal with the public at a later date.â€ FTX did not respond to requests for comment by press time.

According to Yusko on the leaked call, in the event that FTX exercised its option after extending the credit line, only investors in the most senior tranche of the companyâ€™s latest raise would get back anything, and even that would amount to pennies on the dollar.

Morgan Creek, which participated in several funding rounds for BlockFi, would be among those holding the bag.

â€œThe only alternative is to raise an equivalent amount in equity and thatâ€™s what weâ€™re working on,â€ Yusko told investors on the call. â€œI would say it's a 10% possibility but not zero.â€

A recording of the call, which CoinDesk reviewed, offers a rare window into the closed-door negotiations to rescue BlockFi, one of the crypto industryâ€™s largest lenders, amid a meltdown in the digital asset and broader financial markets. It also shows how the current turbulence echoes past financial crises, with Yusko comparing FTXâ€™s rescue package to [J. Pierpont Morganâ€™s bailout of the Knickerbocker Trust in 1907](https://www.federalreservehistory.org/essays/panic-of-1907).

Indeed, Wall Street firm Goldman Sachs has been [trying to organize an investor group](https://www.coindesk.com/business/2022/06/24/goldman-sachs-raising-funds-to-buy-celsius-assets-sources/) to scoop up assets of another troubled crypto lender, Celsius Network, at steep discounts in the event that company files for bankruptcy.

***Read more: [Goldman Sachs Leading Investor Group to Buy Celsius Assets: Sources](https://www.coindesk.com/business/2022/06/24/goldman-sachs-raising-funds-to-buy-celsius-assets-sources/)***

On Friday, the Wall Street Journal [reported](https://www.wsj.com/articles/crypto-exchange-ftx-in-talks-to-acquire-stake-in-blockfi-11656083179) that FTX was in talks to acquire an equity stake in BlockFi. It is unclear whether new developments since Tuesday have substantially changed negotiations.

When asked by an investor on the call, Yusko said Morgan Creek would be open to an â€œin-between dealâ€ where FTX (led by billionaire Sam Bankman-Fried) and Morgan Creek both put up a portion of the capital.

â€œI will definitely try to pursue \[a joint deal\],â€ said Yusko. â€œNot that I have SBF on speed-dial, but I could probably get that call.â€

Yusko said that he spoke with one potential lead investor that could write a $100 million check, as well as two other investors who â€œexpressed interestâ€ and could write checks up to $50 million.

Morgan Creek Digital, co-founded by Anthony â€œPompâ€ Pompliano, is one of BlockFiâ€™s largest investors. The firm has participated in BlockFiâ€™s Series A through D fundraising rounds across three funds and a special purpose vehicle (SPV), a type of investment structure that allows an investor to invest in a single company.

Yusko cautioned that while Morgan Creek was doing all it could to salvage its investment in BlockFi, success was far from assured.

â€œIt's not over, but it is definitely looking dark,â€ he said.
